channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: New York Has The Worst Traffic In The US
item.description: Zoom out: The average metropolitan driver spent ~41 hours in traffic last year, but drivers in the US’ five most-congested metro areas spent much more:New York-Newark: 56Boston: 50Houston: 49Los Angeles-Long Beach-Anaheim: 46San Francisco-Oakland: 46Bottom line: Like the Knicks’ playoff appearance, this traffic ranking is a pandemic-era anomaly.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 1
item.description: (New Yorker) Read: What deadlines do to lifetimes. The department, whose alumni include Meryl Streep and Lupita Nyong’o, will be renamed the David Geffen School of Drama at Yale, proving nothing is truly free.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Amazon Files Motion to Remove Lina Khan From the Company’s Antitrust Investigations
item.description: Amazon filed a motion yesterday to keep Federal Trade Commission Chairwoman Lina Khan out of ongoing antitrust investigations because of her past criticisms of the company. The Yale Law grad was sworn in as chair of the FTC this month.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Finra Levies Robinhood Its Biggest Fine Ever
item.description: Some examples:A feature that was supposed to allow users to block their ability to trade with borrowed money did not work for certain trades. Finra accused Robinhood of misleading customers and for failing to provide support to them when asked. Glitches resulted in traders seeing inaccurate balances. Its IPO paperwork is expected any day now.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: China's Communist Party Turns 100
item.description: Since the liberalization of China’s economy, the country has developed a close business relationship with the West—just last week Nike’s CEO said, “Nike is a brand that is of China and for China.”  After the Communists gained power in the 1949 revolution, Mao initiated a series of disastrous economic reforms that led to the deaths of tens of millions of people. Bottom line: At 100 years old, the Communist Party remains a potent global force led by a president who could be the first since Mao to rule until he dies. Its caginess around the origins of Covid-19 has made things worse.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 1
item.description: (New Yorker) Read: What deadlines do to lifetimes. The department, whose alumni include Meryl Streep and Lupita Nyong’o, will be renamed the David Geffen School of Drama at Yale, proving nothing is truly free.

item.title: China's Communist Party Turns 100
item.description: After the Communists gained power in the 1949 revolution, Mao initiated a series of disastrous economic reforms that led to the deaths of tens of millions of people. Since the liberalization of China’s economy, the country has developed a close economic relationship with the West—just last week Nike’s CEO said, “Nike is a brand that is of China and for China.” Bottom line: At 100 years old, the Communist Party remains a potent global force led by a president who could be the first since Mao to rule until he dies.

item.description: Some examples:A feature that was supposed to allow users to block their ability to trade with borrowed money did not work for certain trades. Finra accused Robinhood of misleading customers and for failing to provide support to them when asked. Glitches resulted in traders seeing inaccurate balances. Its paperwork is expected any day now.

item.title: Amazon Files Motion to Remove Lina Khan From the Company’s Antitrust Investigations
item.description: Amazon filed a motion yesterday to keep Federal Trade Commission Chairwoman Lina Khan out of ongoing antitrust investigations because of her past criticisms of the company. The Yale Law grad was sworn in as chair of the FTC this month.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: The Top Five Business Stories of Q2
item.description: Inflation scaries With prices increasing at rates not seen in years, the No. 1 business story of the quarter could only be inflation. The number of companies citing inflation in their earnings calls hit a 10-year high, Chipotle hiked its menu prices, and at one point in April the cheapest rental car on Maui was a Toyota Camry that cost $722 a day. Fed Chair Jerome Powell has argued higher inflation is mostly transitory, while legendary investor Paul Tudor Jones responded, “that one just doesn’t work the way I see the world.” More Americans quit in May than any month on record. Yet lingering health concerns, childcare responsibilities, and generous unemployment payments have kept Americans from returning to the labor force. With the economy reawakening faster than expected, employers are desperate to hire employees to meet demand. Help wanted9.3 million. 2. For example, in Mississippi less than a third of the population is fully vaccinated.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Time Capsule: Q2 2021
item.description: Here are some of the craziest facts we learned: College coaches were the highest-paid public employees in 40 states in 2019. More twins are being born now than at any point in history.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Facebook Launches Bulletin, Its Subscription Newsletter Service
item.description: Zoom out: Bulletin is Facebook’s latest product that chases individual creators; its previous launch was a Clubhouse competitor for live audio content, which Zuck used to announce Bulletin. The other major competitor in the space is Twitter, after it purchased newsletter platform Revue in January.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 30
item.description: (Paul Graham) Read: How to work hard.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: SpaceX’s Starlink Internet Service Has 69,420 Users
item.description: Musk said Starlink could make up to $30 billion in revenue per year—about 10 times the revenue of the rocket-launching side of SpaceX. Starlink provides internet via a network of over 1,500 satellites orbiting low enough for stargazers to spot them overhead.    But like cheap printers with expensive ink, Starlink hopes to recoup initial costs later on. 69,420, SpaceX CEO Elon Musk said yesterday.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: US Home Price Growth Hits a Record High in April
item.description: Actually, experts predict the housing market won’t implode like it did 10 years ago. Home prices in cities like Phoenix, San Diego, and Seattle are all up more than 20% year over year. “People are kind of burnt out.” Sounds pretty bubbly, right? Another buyer in Austin, TX, bought two houses from the same seller so he could get the one he really wanted.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: United Makes Big Bet on the Future of Air Travel
item.description: Yes, we mean actual business travel “Everything we see every week makes us even more certain that business travel and international travel are ultimately going to come back,” United CEO Scott Kirby said. Fast forward to yesterday, and United Airlines just placed its largest plane order ever and the biggest of any airline in a decade. One does not simply order 270 state-of-the-art planes worth more than $30 billion and then leave them unused in the hangar.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 30
item.description: (Paul Graham) Read: How to work hard.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: SpaceX’s Starlink Internet Service Has 69,420 Users
item.description: 69,420, SpaceX CEO Elon Musk said yesterday. Starlink provides internet via a network of over 1,500 satellites orbiting low enough for stargazers to spot them overhead. He said Starlink could make up to $30 billion in revenue per year—about 10 times the revenue of the rocket-launching side of SpaceX.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Facebook Launches Bulletin, Its Subscription Newsletter Service
item.description: Zoom out: Bulletin is Facebook’s latest product that chases individual creators; its previous launch was a Clubhouse competitor for live audio content, which Zuck used to announce Bulletin. The other major competitor in the space is Twitter, because it purchased newsletter platform Revue in January.

item.title: United Makes Big Bet on the Future of Air Travel
item.description: Yes, we actually mean actual business travel “Everything we see every week makes us even more certain that business travel and international travel are ultimately going to come back,” United CEO Scott Kirby said. Fast forward to yesterday, and United Airlines just placed its largest plane order ever and the biggest of any airline in a decade. One does not simply order 270 state-of-the-art planes worth more than $30 billion and then leave them unopened in the hangar.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: US Home Price Growth Hits a Record High in April
item.description: Actually, experts say the housing market won’t implode like it did 10 years ago. Home prices in cities like Phoenix, San Diego, and Seattle are all up more than 20% year over year. You might be better off getting creative, like these folks: A Bethesda, MD, homebuyer pledged to name her first-born child after the seller in a written offer.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: MWC Returns to Barcelona After One-Year Hiatus
item.description: The line for coffee will be much shorter than usual. Looking ahead... In a non-Covid year, MWC generates $516 million and 14,000 part-time jobs for the local economy. Zoom out: Barcelona hopes enough of those virtual attendees get FOMO and buy plane tickets for next year's show.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 29
item.description: (Vox) Read: Why does it cost so much to build things in America? Kim’s health is closely watched by foreign powers, because he hasn’t appointed a successor.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Two Big Banks Announce Hybrid Work Schedules Amid ‘Get Back to the Office’ Attitude on Wall Street
item.description: Bottom line: Both UBS and Synchrony hope that offering flexible work schedules will help them retain and attract workers, which is necessary since 41% of employees globally are considering leaving their current employer this year.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Facebook Hits $1 Trillion Market Cap After FTC Complaint is Dismissed
item.description: Yesterday was better for Facebook than when Brenda Song agreed to be in The Social Network. while this is a setback for regulators, Facebook isn’t in the clear yet. The first US company to hit a $1 trillion valuation was Apple in 2018, and since then Microsoft, Amazon, and Alphabet have all joined.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Juul Agrees to Pay $40 million to Settle North Carolina Vaping Case
item.description: When Altria, the tobacco giant that owns Marlboro, bought a 35% stake in Juul in 2018, Juul was valued at $38 billion. The same year, the FDA called teen vaping an “epidemic” and started to crack down on Juul and other e-cig companies. Although Juul insisted that its products were intended for adults, its marketing strategies said otherwise... as of last summer, Juul was facing 758 lawsuits across the US. Juul released fruit-flavored pods that went viral among teens (it's pulled most flavors since). That verdict is expected by September.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Juul Agrees to Pay $40 million to Settle North Carolina Vaping Case
item.description: “You only have to walk through any high school parking lot in North Carolina to see how pervasive Juul is among young people in our state,” the state Attorney G Josh Stein said. The same year, the FDA called teen vaping an “epidemic” and started to crack down on Juul and other e-cig companies. When Altria, the tobacco giant that owns Marlboro, bought a 35% stake in Juul in 2018, Juul was valued at $38 billion. The value of Juul plummeted to $4.5 billion. Juul invented fruit flavored e-cigarette pods that went viral among teens. as of July 22, 2020, Juul was facing 758 lawsuits across the US.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Two Big Banks Announce Hybrid Work Schedules Amid ‘Get Back to the Office’ Attitude on Wall Street
item.description: Bottom line: Both UBS and Synchrony hope that offering flexible work schedules will help them retain and attract employees, which is necessary since 41% of employees globally are considering leaving their current employer this year.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Facebook Hits $1 Trillion Market Cap After FTC Complaint is Dismissed
item.description: The FTC has until July 29 to file an amended complaint and, yesterday, the House Judiciary Committee approved all six bills that would give US antitrust law its biggest makeover in decades.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: The Week Ahead: June 28
item.description: The biggest economic event of the week is the release of the June jobs report, which will tell us more about the improving labor market and whether inflation will show up in the form of higher wages.   Got any fun plans?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 28
item.description: (Financial Times) Read: The tyranny of spreadsheets. That means scrapping traveler quarantines, daily case number announcements, and intensive contact tracing efforts.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Intellia Therapeutics Announces Big Gene Editing Breakthrough in Early-Phase Trials
item.description: For the first time, CRISPR technology has been used to successfully treat disease in vivo, or inside the human body. expect Intellia shares, which have gained 233% since its 2016 IPO, to pop today.  Looking ahead... And there’s not many moments in medicine where you get to experience that,” Intellia CEO John Leonard said.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Rescue Workers Continue to Search for Survivors of the Florida Condo Tower Collapse
item.description: Officials are now considering whether or not to temporarily evacuate the sister building, Champlain Towers North, which is located right next door and was built around the same time.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Extra Unemployment Benefits Are Drying Up
item.description: Businesses are desperate to hire workers, and many states think scrapping the extra $300/week in unemployment benefits, which the Biden administration incorporated into its pandemic relief bill, will spur more job-seeking.  In the states that cut off the extra payments the earliest, the number of workers who were paid benefits decreased 13.8% from mid-May to mid-June. On Capitol Hill last week, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said that extra benefits could be playing a role in the worker shortage problem, but focused his attention on other challenges holding back the job market.
item.author: Neal Freyman
